root: Configuration is grouped the same way as the README: defaults, pipelines, modules, baseline, stream, database, webui, and alerts. Each section defines knobs that can be combined to describe how logs are read, labeled, and forwarded.
defaults: defaults: global switches that every module inherits unless a module overrides them. They are useful for setting org wide policies once, such as a minimum severity to analyze.
defaults_llm_enabled: defaults.llm_enabled: true or false to enable LLM payload generation everywhere by default so you do not have to repeat it per pipeline or module.
defaults_llm_min_severity: defaults.llm_min_severity: the lowest severity that should produce an LLM payload when defaults.llm_enabled is true. Accepts INFO, WARNING, ERROR, or CRITICAL.
defaults_max_excerpt_lines: defaults.max_excerpt_lines: hard limit on how many lines around a finding are kept in the excerpt sent to the LLM.
defaults_max_chunk_lines: defaults.max_chunk_lines: legacy cap on excerpt length. Prefer max_excerpt_lines for clarity.
pipelines: pipelines: reusable bundles that marry grouping rules with a classifier. Modules pick a pipeline by name so you can share logic between different log sources.
pipelines_name: pipelines.name: unique identifier for the pipeline. A module references it via modules.pipeline.
pipelines_match: pipelines.match: file selection hints used when multiple pipelines exist and you want a given pipeline to claim only certain files.
match_filename_regex: match.filename_regex: regular expression that marks which log file paths belong to this pipeline.
pipelines_match_filename_regex: pipelines.match.filename_regex: regular expression that marks which log file paths belong to this pipeline.
pipelines_grouping: pipelines.grouping: describes how raw lines are split before classification. Useful when each entry spans multiple lines.
grouping_type: grouping.type: choose whole_file to treat the entire file as one chunk or marker to split on start and end regexes.
pipelines_grouping_type: pipelines.grouping.type: choose whole_file to treat the entire file as one chunk or marker to split on start and end regexes.
grouping_start_regex: grouping.start_regex: when grouping.type is marker, this regex identifies the first line of a chunk.
grouping_end_regex: grouping.end_regex: when grouping.type is marker, this regex identifies the last line of a chunk. Leave empty to let the file end close the final chunk.
pipelines_classifier: pipelines.classifier: selects the classification engine and provides the regex lists that drive severity scoring.
classifier_type: classifier.type: implementation key such as regex_counter or rsnapshot_basic. Choose the classifier that matches your log format.
pipelines_classifier_type: pipelines.classifier.type: implementation key such as regex_counter or rsnapshot_basic. Choose the classifier that matches your log format.
classifier_error_regexes: classifier.error_regexes: list of regex patterns that should count as errors when found in a chunk.
pipelines_classifier_error_regexes: pipelines.classifier.error_regexes: list of regex patterns that should count as errors when found in a chunk.
classifier_warning_regexes: classifier.warning_regexes: list of regex patterns that should count as warnings when found in a chunk.
pipelines_classifier_warning_regexes: pipelines.classifier.warning_regexes: list of regex patterns that should count as warnings when found in a chunk.
classifier_ignore_regexes: classifier.ignore_regexes: list of regex patterns that should be completely skipped before scoring severity.
pipelines_classifier_ignore_regexes: pipelines.classifier.ignore_regexes: list of regex patterns that should be completely skipped before scoring severity.
pipelines_llm: pipelines.llm: per pipeline toggle for LLM payload generation along with an optional template path.
llm_enabled: llm.enabled: true or false to allow this pipeline to emit LLM payloads. Overrides defaults.llm_enabled for this pipeline only.
pipelines_llm_enabled: pipelines.llm.enabled: true or false to allow this pipeline to emit LLM payloads. Overrides defaults.llm_enabled for this pipeline only.
llm_min_severity: llm.min_severity: minimum severity that should produce an LLM payload for this pipeline even if defaults.llm_min_severity differs.
pipelines_llm_min_severity: pipelines.llm.min_severity: minimum severity that should produce an LLM payload for this pipeline even if defaults.llm_min_severity differs.
llm_max_excerpt_lines: llm.max_excerpt_lines: limit on how many log lines to include in the excerpt when this pipeline sends data to the LLM.
pipelines_llm_max_excerpt_lines: pipelines.llm.max_excerpt_lines: limit on how many log lines to include in the excerpt when this pipeline sends data to the LLM.
llm_prompt_template: llm.prompt_template: optional filesystem path to a custom prompt template file that shapes the LLM request.
pipelines_llm_prompt_template: pipelines.llm.prompt_template: optional filesystem path to a custom prompt template file that shapes the LLM request.
pipelines_ignore: pipelines.classifier.ignore_regexes: regexes for log lines that should be ignored when counting severities.
modules: modules: concrete jobs that watch a path using a chosen mode and pipeline. They decide how logs are read and where outputs are delivered.
modules_name: modules.name: friendly identifier for the module that appears in the CLI and Web UI drop downs.
modules_enabled: modules.enabled: on or off switch for the module. Disabled modules are skipped without error.
modules_path: modules.path: the source location to read. In batch mode it can be a single file or a directory, and directories are walked recursively. In follow mode this must be a single file because the follower tracks inode changes and tail offsets; pointing to a directory will not be monitored. For example, use /var/log/app.log for follow mode or /var/log/myapp/ for batch scans.
modules_mode: modules.mode: batch reads everything once, follow tails a single growing log file with rotation awareness, and journal is reserved for possible future journal readers. Follow modules keep their cursor across rotations so the same entry is not processed twice, while batch modules walk directories recursively then exit.
modules_follow: modules.mode = follow: turns the module into a tailer that expects modules.path to point to exactly one file. It remembers the inode to survive rotations, can start at the top or bottom via modules.stream.from_beginning, and keeps scanning until stopped. Use follow for long running agents that must react quickly to fresh log lines rather than reprocessing old archives.
modules_pipeline: modules.pipeline: name of the pipeline that defines grouping and classification for this module. The value must match an entry under pipelines.name; if it is missing or misspelled the module cannot start. Reusing a pipeline across modules lets you point different paths at the same parsing rules, while unique pipelines allow source specific regexes and grouping settings.
modules_output_format: modules.output_format: text prints human friendly findings to stdout with aligned columns and color when available, while json emits a machine readable object per finding that is easy to feed into tools like jq or downstream collectors. Choose text for operators watching the CLI and json for scripted integrations or when piping results into files.
modules_min_print_severity: modules.min_print_severity: filter so that only findings at or above this severity are printed by the module regardless of what the classifier produced below that level. Accepts OK, INFO, WARNING, ERROR, or CRITICAL. This only affects what is shown or emitted, not how exit_code_by_severity is computed, so you can silence INFO noise while still letting ERROR affect exit codes and alerts.
modules_llm: modules.llm: settings that control where and how LLM payload files are written for this module.
llm_emit_llm_payloads_dir: llm.emit_llm_payloads_dir: directory where generated LLM payload files should be saved for this module.
modules_emit_llm_payloads_dir: modules.llm.emit_llm_payloads_dir: directory where generated LLM payload files should be saved for this module.
llm_llm_payload_mode: llm.llm_payload_mode: choose errors_only to emit payloads only for findings flagged as errors or above, or full to include every finding.
modules_llm_payload_mode: modules.llm.llm_payload_mode: choose errors_only to emit payloads only for findings flagged as errors or above, or full to include every finding.
llm_only_last_chunk: llm.only_last_chunk: legacy toggle that looked only at the most recent run. Ignored when running in findings first mode.
modules_only_last_chunk: modules.llm.only_last_chunk: legacy toggle that looked only at the most recent run. Ignored when running in findings first mode.
modules_exit_code_by_severity: modules.exit_code_by_severity: map of severity to exit code for automation. Lets CI fail on ERROR while treating WARNING as success, for example.
exit_code_by_severity_OK: modules.exit_code_by_severity.OK: exit code when the highest severity encountered is OK.
exit_code_by_severity_INFO: modules.exit_code_by_severity.INFO: exit code when the highest severity encountered is INFO.
exit_code_by_severity_WARNING: modules.exit_code_by_severity.WARNING: exit code when the highest severity encountered is WARNING.
exit_code_by_severity_ERROR: modules.exit_code_by_severity.ERROR: exit code when the highest severity encountered is ERROR.
exit_code_by_severity_CRITICAL: modules.exit_code_by_severity.CRITICAL: exit code when the highest severity encountered is CRITICAL.
modules_alerts: modules.alerts: webhook and MQTT delivery points that can be tailored per module with their own severity thresholds.
alerts_webhook: alerts.webhook: HTTP callback settings used when a finding should be pushed to an external service.
modules_alerts_webhook: modules.alerts.webhook: HTTP callback settings used when a finding should be pushed to an external service.
webhook_enabled: alerts.webhook.enabled: true to send webhook payloads, false to disable without removing the rest of the settings.
modules_alerts_webhook_enabled: modules.alerts.webhook.enabled: true to send webhook payloads, false to disable without removing the rest of the settings.
webhook_url: alerts.webhook.url: destination URL that will receive the POST payload with finding details.
modules_alerts_webhook_url: modules.alerts.webhook.url: destination URL that will receive the POST payload with finding details.
webhook_method: alerts.webhook.method: HTTP verb such as POST or PUT used when calling the webhook.
modules_alerts_webhook_method: modules.alerts.webhook.method: HTTP verb such as POST or PUT used when calling the webhook.
webhook_min_severity: alerts.webhook.min_severity: only findings at or above this severity trigger webhook calls.
modules_alerts_webhook_min_severity: modules.alerts.webhook.min_severity: only findings at or above this severity trigger webhook calls.
webhook_headers: alerts.webhook.headers: optional additional headers sent with each request. Provide them as key value pairs.
modules_alerts_webhook_headers: modules.alerts.webhook.headers: optional additional headers sent with each request. Provide them as key value pairs.
modules_alerts_webhook_header_placeholde: modules.alerts.webhook.headers.<header>: placeholder for custom header key names when defining extra headers.
alerts_mqtt: alerts.mqtt: configuration for publishing findings to an MQTT broker.
modules_alerts_mqtt: modules.alerts.mqtt: configuration for publishing findings to an MQTT broker.
mqtt_enabled: alerts.mqtt.enabled: true to publish to MQTT, false to keep MQTT disabled.
modules_alerts_mqtt_enabled: modules.alerts.mqtt.enabled: true to publish to MQTT, false to keep MQTT disabled.
mqtt_host: alerts.mqtt.host: broker host name or IP address.
modules_alerts_mqtt_host: modules.alerts.mqtt.host: broker host name or IP address.
mqtt_port: alerts.mqtt.port: broker port, commonly 1883 unless your deployment uses TLS or a custom port.
modules_alerts_mqtt_port: modules.alerts.mqtt.port: broker port, commonly 1883 unless your deployment uses TLS or a custom port.
mqtt_topic: alerts.mqtt.topic: MQTT topic where findings should be published. Include a clear prefix per environment, such as prod/logtriage/findings.
modules_alerts_mqtt_topic: modules.alerts.mqtt.topic: MQTT topic where findings should be published. Include a clear prefix per environment, such as prod/logtriage/findings.
mqtt_username: alerts.mqtt.username: username used when connecting to the broker if authentication is required.
modules_alerts_mqtt_username: modules.alerts.mqtt.username: username used when connecting to the broker if authentication is required.
mqtt_password: alerts.mqtt.password: password used when connecting to the broker if authentication is required.
modules_alerts_mqtt_password: modules.alerts.mqtt.password: password used when connecting to the broker if authentication is required.
mqtt_min_severity: alerts.mqtt.min_severity: only findings at or above this severity are published to MQTT.
modules_alerts_mqtt_min_severity: modules.alerts.mqtt.min_severity: only findings at or above this severity are published to MQTT.
modules_baseline: modules.baseline: anomaly detection settings that compare current counts to historical averages and bump severity when counts spike.
baseline: baseline: anomaly detection settings that compare current counts to historical averages and bump severity when counts spike.
baseline_enabled: baseline.enabled: true to enable anomaly detection for this module, false to ignore baseline logic.
modules_baseline_enabled: modules.baseline.enabled: true to enable anomaly detection for this module, false to ignore baseline logic.
baseline_state_file: baseline.state_file: JSON file that stores the historical counts used to detect anomalies. It should live somewhere persistent across runs.
modules_baseline_state_file: modules.baseline.state_file: JSON file that stores the historical counts used to detect anomalies. It should live somewhere persistent across runs.
baseline_window: baseline.window: number of past runs to keep when computing rolling averages.
modules_baseline_window: modules.baseline.window: number of past runs to keep when computing rolling averages.
baseline_error_multiplier: baseline.error_multiplier: multiplier applied to the historical average of errors. If the current count exceeds this product, the run is flagged as anomalous.
modules_baseline_error_multiplier: modules.baseline.error_multiplier: multiplier applied to the historical average of errors. If the current count exceeds this product, the run is flagged as anomalous.
baseline_warning_multiplier: baseline.warning_multiplier: multiplier applied to the historical average of warnings. If the current count exceeds this product, the run is flagged as anomalous.
modules_baseline_warning_multiplier: modules.baseline.warning_multiplier: multiplier applied to the historical average of warnings. If the current count exceeds this product, the run is flagged as anomalous.
baseline_severity_on_anomaly: baseline.severity_on_anomaly: severity to assign when an anomaly is detected. Set to WARNING or higher to make anomalies visible in alerts and exit codes.
modules_baseline_severity_on_anomaly: modules.baseline.severity_on_anomaly: severity to assign when an anomaly is detected. Set to WARNING or higher to make anomalies visible in alerts and exit codes.
modules_stream: modules.stream: stream and tailing controls that apply when modules.mode is follow.
stream_from_beginning: stream.from_beginning: true starts reading at the top of the file, false starts at the end like tail -F.
modules_stream_from_beginning: modules.stream.from_beginning: true starts reading at the top of the file, false starts at the end like tail -F.
stream_interval: stream.interval: pause in seconds between checks for new lines while following a file. Smaller values react faster; larger values reduce CPU use.
modules_stream_interval: modules.stream.interval: pause in seconds between checks for new lines while following a file. Smaller values react faster; larger values reduce CPU use.
database: database: connection string and retention policy used by both CLI and Web UI to store findings history.
database_url: database.url: SQLAlchemy connection URL such as sqlite:///file.db or a PostgreSQL DSN.
database_retention_days: database.retention_days: number of days to keep stored findings before cleanup routines prune them.
webui: webui: HTTP server options including host, port, base_path, and security controls like secret_key, allowed_ips, and admin_users.
webui_enabled: webui.enabled: master switch to turn the Web UI on or off.
webui_host: webui.host: interface where the Web UI binds, for example 0.0.0.0 to listen on all addresses inside a container.
webui_port: webui.port: TCP port for the Web UI server.
webui_base_path: webui.base_path: prefix the UI should expect when running behind a reverse proxy that rewrites paths, such as /logtriage.
webui_secret_key: webui.secret_key: long random string used for signing sessions. Rotate it to invalidate existing sessions.
webui_session_cookie_name: webui.session_cookie_name: override the cookie name to avoid collisions when hosting multiple apps on the same domain.
webui_dark_mode_default: webui.dark_mode_default: true defaults the UI to dark mode for new users, false defaults to light mode.
webui_csrf_enabled: webui.csrf_enabled: toggle CSRF protection for form submissions.
webui_allowed_ips: webui.allowed_ips: list of IPs allowed to reach the UI. Leave empty to allow all clients, or provide specific addresses for a private deployment.
webui_admin_users: webui.admin_users: list of admin credentials, each with username and password_hash fields.
admin_users_username: webui.admin_users.username: admin login name displayed on the sign in form.
webui_admin_username: webui.admin_users.username: admin login name displayed on the sign in form.
admin_users_password_hash: webui.admin_users.password_hash: bcrypt or compatible hash for the admin password.
webui_admin_password_hash: webui.admin_users.password_hash: bcrypt or compatible hash for the admin password.
alerts: alerts: shared alert settings reused across modules when they do not override webhook or MQTT options.
